presets.shortdescription: Default OpenStreetMap Preset for Vespucci and JOSM
presets.description: General purpose OpenStreetMap preset for Vespucci and JOSM, based on the original JOSM version

list_entry.short_description: Robust Wheels: trekking bike, car, rickshaw
High Clearance: light duty off-road vehicle
0: Solid gravel/packed earth, no obstacles, wide curves
1: Some loose surface, small obstacles, wide curves
2: Much loose surface, large obstacles, easy hairpins
3: Slippery surface, large obstacles, tight hairpins
4: Loose surface or boulders, dangerous hairpins
0: Graveled or hardened earth. Good Grip. Avg. incline 10%
1: Graveled or hardened earth. Good Grip. Avg. incline 15%
2: Mostly stable, unsurfaced, partly washed out
3: Variable Surface, tight corners, small steps, surface rocks, earth or grass.
4: Way is very steep, or in bad condition for pedalling uphill. Steps, trees, roots, tight corners.
5: Way is too steep and/or too difficult to ride uphill.

list_entry.short_description: Full post office operated by 3rd party
Plants that are leafless for a certain period during the year.
Plants that are never entirely without green foliage.
Plants that lose their foliage for a very short period, when old leaves fall off and new foliage growth is starting.
Plants that lose most, but not all, of their foliage for a fraction of the year.
Plants that are leafless for a certain period during the year.
Plants that are never entirely without green foliage.
Plants that lose their foliage for a very short period, when old leaves fall off and new foliage growth is starting.
Plants that lose most, but not all, of their foliage for a fraction of the year.
Habitat with evergreen and deciduous vegetation.
Trees remarkable due to its size or prominent location, usually visible from great distances and useful for navigation.
Especially old tree, often with a particular shape. Usually protected for its uniqueness.
Trees found within settlements, e.g. in parks or spread through residential areas.

list_entry.short_description: A sauna is available but its type is not specified.
A Finnish-style sauna with a temperature of over 60°C because of the water thrown on the rocks of the stove. This kind of sauna is relatively dry because of the high temperature.
A Turkish-style steam sauna with a lower temperature and limited visibility because of the steam generated.
A sauna-like construction that is used for infrared therapy.
A non-steam dry sauna in which water is not thrown on the stove.
A Finnish-style hot sauna in which the stove has no chimney but instead the smoke fills the room when the sauna is prepared, and the smoke is then ventilated out when the sauna is ready.
A Korean-style hot and dry sauna, in which water is not thrown on the stove.
A sauna that constantly has an aroma, NOT a Finnish sauna with occasional aroma liquid added to the water.

list_entry.short_description: Robust Wheels: trekking bike, car, rickshaw
High Clearance: light duty off-road vehicle
Robust Wheels: trekking bike, car, rickshaw
High Clearance: light duty off-road vehicle
Usually a paved or heavily compacted hardcore surface
Usually an unpaved track with surface of gravel mixed with a varying amount of sand, silt, and clay
Even mixture of hard and soft materials
Almost always an unpaved track prominently with soil/sand/grass, but with some hard materials, or compressed materials
Almost always an unpaved track lacking hard materials, uncompacted, with surface of soil/sand/grass
Trail well cleared. Area flat or slightly sloped, no fall hazard
Trail with continuous line and balanced ascent. Terrain partially steep, fall hazard possible
exposed sites may be secured with ropes or chains, possible need to use hands for balance. Partly exposed sites with fall hazard, scree, pathless jagged rocks

list_entry.display_value: T4 - difficult, exposed, steep alpine trail
list_entry.short_description: sometimes need for hand use to get ahead. Terrain quite exposed, precarious grassy acclivities, jagged rocks, facile snow-free glaciers

list_entry.display_value: T5 - difficult alpine trail with climbing
list_entry.short_description: single plainly climbing up to second grade. Exposed, demanding terrain, jagged rocks, few dangerous glacier and snow

list_entry.display_value: T6 - hazardous alpine trail with climbing
list_entry.short_description: climbing up to second grade. Often very exposed, precarious jagged rocks, glacier with danger to slip and fall
Marked footpath in a parking lot
Footway sections that do not exist but are necessary for routing
Footway sections inside a crossing island
Access for back entrances and/or emergency access

In case of traffic signals:
Used for local orientation, or for references.
Tags which are implied and do not need to be set are:
`access=no`, `foot=yes` and `bicycle=yes`
The tag `foot=yes` is implied and does not need to be set.
Tags which are implied and do not need to be set are:
`motor_vehicle=no`, `psv=yes`, `foot=yes` and `bicycle=yes`
A pedestrian door or gate near a larger gate
The tag `foot=yes` is implied and does not need to be set.

label.text: An area in which waterborn tailings are pumped to allow the separation of solids from the water
A body of water, such as a lake or pond.
Line between the sea and land (with the water on the right side of the way).
Waterlogged area, either permanently or seasonally with vegetation.
Large area covered with mud.
A flat area of sand, gravel or pebble next to water.
An area of water mostly surrounded by land but with level connection to the ocean or a lake.
A prominent, elevated piece of land sticking out into the sea or large lake.
Fuel types:
OpenSeaMap and other nautical projects use a special tagging scheme. If you intend to add or edit such objects you should install a dedicated preset.

list_entry.short_description: An area in which vessels anchor or may anchor.
A designated area of water where a single vessel, sea plane etc. may anchor.
A beacon used in conjunction with the compass to indicate where the mariner may find the best navigable water.
A beacon that is moored on or above an isolated danger of limited extent, which has navigable water all around it.
A beacon used to indicate the port or starboard hand side of the route to be followed.
A beacon used to indicate that there is navigable water around the mark.
A beacon primarily used to indicate an area or feature, the nature of which is apparent from reference to a chart, Sailing Directions or Notices to Mariners.
A named or numbered place where a vessel is moored at a wharf.
A structure erected over a body of water, railroad, etc. to provide a roadway for vehicles, pedestrians or to carry utility services.
A station, at which a ship is able to bunker fuel, water or ballast.
A relatively permanent structure, roofed and usually walled. It is designed for some particular use which it may be important to indicate.
A buoy used in conjunction with the compass to indicate where the mariner may find the best navigable water.
A buoy used for loading tankers with gas or oil.
A buoy that is moored on or above an isolated danger of limited extent, which has navigable water all around it.
A buoy used to indicate the port or starboard hand side of the route to be followed.
A buoy used to indicate that there is navigable water around the mark.
A buoy primarily used to indicate an area or feature, the nature of which is apparent from reference to a chart, Sailing Directions or Notices to Mariners.
An area which contains one or more submarine cables.
An overhead cable is an assembly of wires or fibres, or a wire rope or chain, which is supported by structures such as poles or pylons and passing over or nearby navigable waters.
An assembly of wires or fibres, or a wire rope or chain which has been laid underwater or buried beneath the seabed.
A raised way across low or wet ground or water.
An official place to register, declare or check goods and people.
Watch keeping stations at which a watch is kept either continuously, or at certain times only.
Indicates the coverage of an area, in which a vessel has to report or may request information.
A machine for lifting, shifting and lowering objects or materials by means of a swinging boom or with a lifting apparatus.
A point on the ground where position (horizontal and vertical) is used as a base for a dependent survey. Also referred to as a control station.
The identifying characteristics of an aid to navigation which serve to facilitate its recognition against a daylight viewing background.
A distance mark indicates the distance measured from an origin and consists of either a solid visible structure or a distinct location without special installation.
An area of the bottom of a body of water which has been deepened by dredging.
A sea area where dredged material or other potentially more harmful material, e.g. explosives, chemical waste, is deliberately deposited.
An exceptional navigational construction like aqueduct, lift-lock, etc.
That part of a river, harbour and so on, where the main navigable channel for vessels of larger size lies.
A route in a body of water where a ferry crosses from one shoreline to another.
A man-made barrier used as an enclosure or boundary or for protection.
A warning signal transmitted by a vessel, or aid to navigation, during periods of low visibility.
A structure that is specifically designed or reinforced to provide for defence from armed attack.
A structure in shallow water for fishing purposes which can be an obstruction to ships in general.
A structure that may be swung, drawn, or lowered to block an entrance or passageway.
A structure in the intertidal zone serving as a support for vessels at low stages of the tide to permit work on the exposed portion of the vessel's hull.
An enclosed area of water surrounded by quay walls constructed to provide means for the transfer of cargos from and to ships.
A Harbour installation with a service or commercial operation of public interest. A body of water providing protection for vessels, and providing anchoring and docking facilities.
The hull of a wrecked or condemned ship, which is moored in a permanent position or grounded.

A routing measure comprising a designated area between the landward boundary of a traffic separation scheme and the adjacent coast, to be used in accordance with the provisions of the International Regulations for Preventing Collisions at Sea.
A prominent object at a fixed location which can be used in determining a location or a direction.

A luminous or lighted aid to navigation. Light. Lighthouse. An all around light is a light that is visible over the whole horizon of interest to marine navigation. Secotr lights present different appearances (in particular, different colours) over various parts of the horizon of interest to maritime navigation.

An important luminous aid to navigation, light, lighthouse, to which a name can be attributed. Generally, a major light may be considered to be a light intended for use at sea, usually with a range of 15 miles or more, and in outer approaches to harbours. The IALA Maritime Buoyage System rules (INT-1 Q 130) do not apply for most landfall lights. In general, sector lights follow IALA convention when used for marking a channel.
A luminous or lighted aid to navigation, light. The IALA Maritime Buoyage System rules (INT-1 Q 130) will apply to minor lights, but not to leading lights.
A boat-like structure used instead of a light buoy in waters where strong streams or currents are experienced, or when a greater elevation than that of a light buoy is necessary.
A distinctively marked vessel anchored or moored at a charted point, to serve as an important floating aid to navigation with major light.
A lock basin is a wet dock in a waterway, permitting a ship to pass from one level to another.
An assemblage of cages, nets, rafts and floats or posts where fish, including shellfish, are artificially cultivated.
An area within which naval, military or aerial exercises are carried out. Also called an 'exercise area'.
The equipment or structure used to secure a vessel.
A straight line extending towards an area of navigational interest and generally generated by two navigational aids or one navigational aid and a bearing.

A notice board or sign indicating information to the mariner. A signboard used to indicate prohibitions, regulations, restrictions, recommendations and general information which apply to a waterway or a section of a waterway.

In marine navigation, anything that hinders or prevents movement, particularly anything that endangers or prevents passage of a vessel. Areas over which it is safe to navigate but which should be avoided for anchoring, taking the ground or ground fishing.
A construction to dam oil flow on water.
A permanent offshore structure, either fixed or floating, used in the production of oil or natural gas.
An area at sea within which there are production facilities.
The meeting place to which the pilot comes out.
A long heavy timber or section of steel, wood, concrete, etc. forced into the earth which may serve as a support, as for a pier, or a free standing pole within a marine environment.
An area containing one or more pipelines.
An overhead pipeline is a pipeline supported by pylons and passing over or nearby navigable waters.
A connected set of pipes for conveying liquids, slurries, or gases. A pipeline lying on or buried under the seabed or the land.
A floating structure, usually rectangular in shape which serves as landing, pier head or bridge support.
A routeing measure comprising an area within defined limits where ships must navigate with particular caution and within which the direction of traffic flow may be recommended.
A vertical construction consisting, for example, of a steel framework or pre-stressed concrete to carry cables, a bridge, etc.
Recommended tracks along which ships can be guided by coastal radar stations in the event of bad visibility. Also known as a radar guided track.
Indicates the coverage of a sea area by a radar surveillance station. Inside this area a vessel may request shore-based radar assistance, particularly in poor visibility.
A device capable of, or intended for, reflecting radar signals.
A transponder beacon transmitting a coded signal on radar frequency, permitting an interrogating craft to determine the bearing and range of the transponder. Also called racon.
A station with a transmitter emitting pulses of ultra-high frequency radio waves which are reflected by solid objects and are detected upon their return to the sending station.
On passing a radio calling-in point or crossing a defined line vessels are required to report on VHF to a Traffic Control Centre.
A place equipped to transmit radio waves.
A recommended route centerline indicates the 'centerline' of a recommended route (often marked by centerline buoys).

A route which has been specially examined to ensure so far as possible that it is free of dangers and along which ships are advised to navigate. That portion of a 'navigation line' that a ship should use for navigation.

A traffic flow pattern indicating a recommended directional movement of traffic where it is impractical or unnecessary to adopt an established direction of traffic flow. Indicates the recommended traffic flow e.g., between two TSS, in the entrance areas of a TSS, beside a deep water route.
A place where equipment for saving life at sea is maintained. Also called life saving station.
A specified area on land or water designated by an appropriate authority within which access or navigation is restricted in accordance with certain specified conditions.
A means of distinguishing unlighted marks at night. Retro-reflective material is secured to the mark in a particular pattern to reflect back light.
A large mobile wave-like sediment feature in shallow water and composed of sand. The wavelength may reach 100 metres, the amplitude may be up to 20 metres.

A region of the seabed including the material of which it is composed and its physical characteristics. Also called nature of bottom, character (or characteristics) of the bottom, or quality of the bottom.
A geographically defined part of the sea or other navigable waters. It may be specified within its limits by its proper name.

Any of various submerged monocotyledonous plants (such as Posidonia, eelgrass (Zostera), tape grass (Hydrocharitaceae), turtle grass (Thalassia testudinum) and other Cymodoceaceae) of tropical to temperate usually shallow coastal waters that have narrow grasslike leaves and often form dense underwater meadows. (now distinct from Weed/Kelp, macroscopic marine algae), see change and symbol proposed for S-4 and S-101 DCEG.
A designated portion of water for the landing and take-off of sea-planes.
A large storage structure used for storing loose materials, liquids and/or gases.
A fixed artificial structure in the water and/or adjoining the land. It may also refer to features such as training walls, which are not necessarily connected to, nor form part of the shoreline.
A traffic signal station is a place on shore from which signals are made to regulate the movement of traffic.
A warning signal station is a place on shore from which warning signals are made to ships at sea.
A place at which a service generally of interest to small craft or pleasure boats is available.
A natural issue of water or other substances from the earth. One on the bottom of the sea is called a 'submarine spring'.
A lane where submarines may navigate under water or at the surface.
A characteristic shape secured at the top of a buoy or beacon to aid in its identification.
The outer limit of a traffic lane part or a traffic separation scheme roundabout.
A defined area where traffic lanes cross.
An area within defined limits in which one-way traffic flow is established.

A line separating the lanes in which ships are proceeding in opposite, or nearly opposite directions; or separating a traffic lane from an adjacent sea area; or separating traffic lanes designated for particular classes of ships proceeding in the same direction.

A routeing measure comprising a separation point or circular separation zone and a circular traffic lane within defined limits. Traffic within the roundabout is separated by moving in a counter clockwise direction around the separation point or zone.

A zone separating the lanes in which ships are proceeding in opposite or nearly opposite directions; or separating a traffic lane from an adjacent sea area; or separating traffic lanes designated for particular classes of ships proceeding in the same direction.
An area of water or enlargement of a channel used for turning vessels.
An area of a two-way route within which traffic flow is generally along one bearing.
A concreted mass of stony material or coral which dries, is awash or is below the water surface.
Plants collectively or individually, especially those dominating a particular area or habitat.
An Automatic Identification System (AIS) message 21 transmitted from an AIS station to simulate on navigation systems an Aid to Navigation which does not physically exist.
A place where vehicles can be loaded or unloaded from the inland vessel with onboard or on-shore facilities.
The disturbance of water caused by the interaction of any combination of waves, currents, tidal streams, wind, shoal patches and obstructions.
A waterway gauge is an instrument for measuring water levels.

Any macroscopic marine algae. Kelp is one of an order (laminariales) of usually large, blade-shaped or vine-like brown algae. (now excluding seagrass), see change and symbol proposed for S-4 and S-101 DCEG.
The ruined remains of a stranded or sunken vessel which has been rendered useless.

label.text: (Please only use this tag if more detailed mapping using busbars and bays is impossible!)
Pole Attributes:
Switch Attributes:
Pole Attributes:
Transformer Attributes:

list_entry.short_description: Forts using a rise of elevation
Raised area of ground for a castle
A group of artillary (cannon) in a fixed fortification
Like a statue, but only showing the upper half of a person.
A commemorative sign, often mounted on a wall.
An upright slab engraved or painted with decorations or inscriptions.
A stone with an inscription, picture, or similar.
A building, monument, statue or other edifice celebrating a victory or commemorating those who died or were injured in a war.
A non figurative sculpture which does not match any of the other categories.
A blue plaque commemorating a historical link to that location. (UK)
A bicycle painted white permanently placed as memorial for a victim of a road accident (usually cyclists).
10cm × 10cm brass plaque commemorating victims of Nazi persecution. (EU,RU)
A bench placed in memory of someone or something; usually has a plaque, and sometimes a statue sitting on (part of) it.

label.text: A farm within a bigger settlement
(please use isolated_dwelling for an isolated farm)
The top (summit) of a mountain or hill.
A saddle point between mountains or hills.
A persistent body of dense ice that is constantly moving under its own weight.
A volcano, either dormant, extinct or active.
A mountain or hill ridge.
A low area between hills.
A steep rock face exposure, with a significant vertical, or near vertical (leave the lower face to the right of the way).
A steep earth bank, with a significant vertical, or near vertical (leave the lower face to the right of the way).
The entrance to a cave.
A single tree.
A line of trees.
A tree stump.
A single shrub.
An area of shrubbery that is actively maintained or pruned by humans.

list_entry.short_description: Sparsely planted shrubbery. Generally speaking able-bodied persons could walk through them (although this is usually not desirable).
Shrubbery with a medium density. Able-bodied persons might be able to barge through it, but it takes some effort and might result in scratches or soiled clothing.
Densely planted shrubbery. Effectively impassible without damaging the shrubbery (which at this point often acts as a hedge) and getting your clothes torn.

label.text: Woodland where timber production does not dominate use.
Where vegetation is dominated by grasses (Poaceae) and other herbaceous (non-woody) plants. Excludes cultivated areas and wetlands.
An accumulation of loose rocks.
An accumulation of loose rounded rocks on a beach or riverbed.
Bare upper lying uncultivated land principally covered with grass and often grazed.
Bare lower lying uncultivated land with bushes but little or no tree cover.
Bare lower lying uncultivated land with a shrubland habitat found mainly on free-draining infertile, acidic soils, and is characterised by open, low-growing woody vegetation.
Large area covered with sand.
For areas of solid visible rock that is sparsely vegetated or not vegetated at all.
A notable rock or group of rocks, with at least one of them firmly attached to the underlying bedrock.
A single notable free-standing rock, which may differ from the composition of the terrain it lies in.

combo.display_values: Almond trees,Apple trees,Apricot trees,Avocado trees,Banana plants,Blueberry plants,Cacao trees,Cherimoya trees,Cherry trees,Chestnut trees,Coconut palms,Coffea plants,Date palms,Hazel plants,Hop plants,Lemon trees,Macadamia trees,Mango trees,Oil palms,Olive trees,Orange trees,Papaya trees,Peach trees,Pear trees,Pecan trees,Persimmon trees,Pineapple plants,Pistachio trees,Pitaya plants,Plum trees,Pomegranate trees,Tea plants,Walnut trees
Chinese,Cottage garden,English,Flower garden,French,Herb garden,Japanese,Kitchen,Medical garden,Monastery,Rosarium,Walled garden,Zen

preset_link.text: Similar tags but different tagging schema:
Similar tags but different tagging schema:

label.text: A short text with additional information.
It might be viewable to the end user (perhaps using a search system or a map with pop-ups).
An important hint for other mappers (not for the end user).
A hint for other mappers (not for the end user), that an object needs an improvement.

text.javascript: function addCheckDate(key) { df = new java.text.SimpleDateFormat('yyyy-MM-dd'); v = new java.util.ArrayList(); v.add(df.format(new java.util.Date())); tags.put(key,v); } for (var key in Iterator(new java.util.HashSet(tags.keySet()))) { if (key.startsWith('check_date:')) { addCheckDate(key); } } addCheckDate('check_date'); tags.remove('automatic_check_date');

text.javascript: var objects = ['amenity','aeroway','building','highway','leisure','man_made','military','railway','shop']; function isObject(key) { var objectsLength = objects.length; for (var i = 0; i < objectsLength; i++) { if (objects[i].equals(key)) { return true; } } return false; } for (var key in Iterator(new java.util.HashSet(tags.keySet()))) { if (isObject(key)) { tags.put('disused:'+key,tags.get(key)); tags.remove(key); } } tags.remove('set_to_disused');

var objects = ['amenity','aeroway','building','highway','leisure','man_made','military','railway','shop']; function isObject(key) { var objectsLength = objects.length; for (var i = 0; i < objectsLength; i++) { if (objects[i].equals(key)) { return true; } } return false; } var presetItem = null; for (var key in Iterator(new java.util.HashSet(tags.keySet()))) { if (isObject(key)) { tags.put('disused:'+key,tags.get(key)); presetItem = key2PresetItem.get(key); tags.remove(key); } if (typeof versionCode !== 'undefined' && versionCode > 703) { if (presetItem !== null && presetItem.equals(key2PresetItem.get(key))) { tags.remove(key); } } } tags.remove('set_to_disused_remove_tags');
